segment.source: Lab 2a: Answer files: Update settings and run scripts
segment.target: Lab 2a: Answer files: Update settings and run scripts

segment.source: Lab 2a: Answer files: Update settings and run scripts
segment.target: Lab 2a: Answer files: Update settings and run scripts

segment.source: Lab 2a: Answer files: Update settings and run scripts
segment.target: Lab 2a: Answer files: Update settings and run scripts

segment.source: Answer files (or Unattend files) can be used to modify Windows settings in your images during Setup.
segment.target: Answer files (or Unattend files) can be used to modify Windows settings in your images during Setup.

segment.source: You can also create scripts that you can inject into your offline images, so that you can efficiently make changes to multiple images without ever booting them.
segment.target: You can also create scripts that you can inject into your offline images, so that you can efficiently make changes to multiple images without ever booting them.

segment.source: diagram of creating a new answer file
segment.target: diagram of creating a new answer file

segment.source: Windows settings overview
segment.target: Windows settings overview

segment.source: While you can set many Windows settings in audit mode, some settings can only be set by using an answer file or Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD), such as adding manufacturer’s support information.
segment.target: While you can set many Windows settings in audit mode, some settings can only be set by using an answer file or Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD), such as adding manufacturer’s support information.

segment.source: A full list of answer file settings (also known as Unattend settings) is in the Unattended Windows Setup Reference.
segment.target: A full list of answer file settings (also known as Unattend settings) is in the Unattended Windows Setup Reference.

segment.source: Enterprises can control other settings by using Group Policy.
segment.target: Enterprises can control other settings by using Group Policy.

segment.source: For more info, see Group Policy.
segment.target: For more info, see Group Policy.

segment.source: You canspecify which configuration pass to add new settings:
segment.target: You canspecify which configuration pass to add new settings:

segment.source: 1 windowsPE: These settings are used by the Windows Setup installation program.
segment.target: 1 windowsPE: These settings are used by the Windows Setup installation program.

segment.source: If you’re modifying existing images, you can usually ignore these settings.
segment.target: If you’re modifying existing images, you can usually ignore these settings.

segment.source: 4 specialize: Most settings should be added here.
segment.target: 4 specialize: Most settings should be added here.

segment.source: These settings are triggered both at the beginning of audit mode and at the beginning of OOBE.
segment.target: These settings are triggered both at the beginning of audit mode and at the beginning of OOBE.

segment.source: If you need to make multiple updates or test settings, generalize the device again and add another batch of settings in the Specialize Configuration pass.
segment.target: If you need to make multiple updates or test settings, generalize the device again and add another batch of settings in the Specialize Configuration pass.

segment.source: 6 auditUser: Runs as soon as you start audit mode.
segment.target: 6 auditUser: Runs as soon as you start audit mode.

segment.source: This is a great time to run a system test script - we'll add Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentRunAsynchronousCommand as our example.
segment.target: This is a great time to run a system test script - we'll add Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentRunAsynchronousCommand as our example.

segment.source: To learn more, see Add a Custom Script to Windows Setup.
segment.target: To learn more, see Add a Custom Script to Windows Setup.

segment.source: 7 oobeSystem: Use sparingly.
segment.target: 7 oobeSystem: Use sparingly.

segment.source: Most of these settings run after the user completes OOBE.
segment.target: Most of these settings run after the user completes OOBE.

segment.source: The exception is the Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentResealMode = Audit setting, which we’ll use to bypass OOBE and boot the PC into audit mode.
segment.target: The exception is the Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentResealMode = Audit setting, which we’ll use to bypass OOBE and boot the PC into audit mode.

segment.source: If your script relies on knowing which language the user selects during OOBE, you’d add it to the oobeSystem pass.
segment.target: If your script relies on knowing which language the user selects during OOBE, you’d add it to the oobeSystem pass.

segment.source: For info on the other configuration passes, see Windows Setup Configuration Passes.
segment.target: For info on the other configuration passes, see Windows Setup Configuration Passes.

segment.source: Note These settings could be lost if the user resets their PC with the built-in recovery tools.
segment.target: Note These settings could be lost if the user resets their PC with the built-in recovery tools.

segment.source: To see how to make sure these settings stay on the device during a reset, see Sample scripts: Keeping Windows settings through a recovery.
segment.target: To see how to make sure these settings stay on the device during a reset, see Sample scripts: Keeping Windows settings through a recovery.

segment.source: Create and modify an answer file
segment.target: Create and modify an answer file

segment.source: Create a catalog file
segment.target: Create a catalog file

segment.source: Start Windows System Image Manager.
segment.target: Start Windows System Image Manager.

segment.source: On the File menu, click Select Windows Image.
segment.target: On the File menu, click Select Windows Image.

segment.source: In the Select a Windows Image dialog, browse to and select the base-image file.
segment.target: In the Select a Windows Image dialog, browse to and select the base-image file.

segment.source: Next, select an edition of Windows, for example, Windows 10 Pro, and click OK.
segment.target: Next, select an edition of Windows, for example, Windows 10 Pro, and click OK.

segment.source: Click Yes to create the catalog file.
segment.target: Click Yes to create the catalog file.

segment.source: Windows SIM creates the file based on the base-image file, and saves it to the Windows desktop.
segment.target: Windows SIM creates the file based on the base-image file, and saves it to the Windows desktop.

segment.source: This process can take several minutes.
segment.target: This process can take several minutes.

segment.source: The catalog file appears in the Windows Image pane.
segment.target: The catalog file appears in the Windows Image pane.

segment.source: Windows SIM also lists the configurable components and packages in that image.
segment.target: Windows SIM also lists the configurable components and packages in that image.

segment.source: Troubleshooting: If Windows SIM does not create the catalog file, try the following steps:
segment.target: Troubleshooting: If Windows SIM does not create the catalog file, try the following steps:

segment.source: Make sure you are using a Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education) version of the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) tools.
segment.target: Make sure you are using a Windows 10 for desktop editions (Home, Pro, Enterprise, and Education) version of the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK) tools.

segment.source: To create a catalog file for either 32-bit or ARM-based devices, use a 32-bit device.
segment.target: To create a catalog file for either 32-bit or ARM-based devices, use a 32-bit device.

segment.source: Make sure the Windows base-image file (SourcesInstall.wim) is in a folder that has read-write privileges, such as a USB flash drive or on your hard drive.
segment.target: Make sure the Windows base-image file (SourcesInstall.wim) is in a folder that has read-write privileges, such as a USB flash drive or on your hard drive.

segment.source: Create an answer file
segment.target: Create an answer file

segment.source: On the File menu, click New Answer File.
segment.target: On the File menu, click New Answer File.

segment.source: The new answer file appears in the Answer File pane.
segment.target: The new answer file appears in the Answer File pane.

segment.source: Note If you open an existing answer file, you might be prompted to associate the answer file with the image.
segment.target: Note If you open an existing answer file, you might be prompted to associate the answer file with the image.

segment.source: Click Yes.
segment.target: Click Yes.

segment.source: Add new answer file settings
segment.target: Add new answer file settings

segment.source: Set the device to automatically boot to audit mode:
segment.target: Set the device to automatically boot to audit mode:

segment.source: In the Windows Image pane, expand Components, right-click amd64Microsoft-Windows-Deployment(version), and then select Add Setting to Pass 7 oobeSystem.
segment.target: In the Windows Image pane, expand Components, right-click amd64Microsoft-Windows-Deployment(version), and then select Add Setting to Pass 7 oobeSystem.

segment.source: In the Answer File pane, select Components7 oobeSystemamd64Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentneutralReseal.
segment.target: In the Answer File pane, select Components7 oobeSystemamd64Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentneutralReseal.

segment.source: In the Reseal Properties pane, in the Settings section, select Mode=.
segment.target: In the Reseal Properties pane, in the Settings section, select Mode=.

segment.source: Prepare a script to run after Audit mode begins.
segment.target: Prepare a script to run after Audit mode begins.

segment.source: In the Windows Image pane, right-click amd64 Microsoft-Windows-Deployment(version) and then click Add Setting to Pass 6 auditUser.
segment.target: In the Windows Image pane, right-click amd64 Microsoft-Windows-Deployment(version) and then click Add Setting to Pass 6 auditUser.

segment.source: In the Answer File pane, expand Components6 auditUseramd64Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentneutralRunAsynchronous.
segment.target: In the Answer File pane, expand Components6 auditUseramd64Microsoft-Windows-DeploymentneutralRunAsynchronous.

segment.source: Right-click RunAsynchronousCommand Properties and click Insert New AsynchronousCommand.
segment.target: Right-click RunAsynchronousCommand Properties and click Insert New AsynchronousCommand.

segment.source: In the AsynchronousCommand Properties pane, in the Settings section, add the following values:
segment.target: In the AsynchronousCommand Properties pane, in the Settings section, add the following values:

segment.source: Save the answer file
segment.target: Save the answer file

segment.source: Save the answer file, for example: C:AnswerFilesBootToAudit-x64.xml.
segment.target: Save the answer file, for example: C:AnswerFilesBootToAudit-x64.xml.

segment.source: Note Windows SIM will not allow you to save the answer file into the mounted image folders.
segment.target: Note Windows SIM will not allow you to save the answer file into the mounted image folders.

segment.source: Create a script
segment.target: Create a script

segment.source: Copy the following sample script into Notepad, and save it as C:AnswerFilesSampleCommand.cmd.
segment.target: Copy the following sample script into Notepad, and save it as C:AnswerFilesSampleCommand.cmd.

segment.source: Add the answer file and script to the image
segment.target: Add the answer file and script to the image

segment.source: Mount the Windows image.
segment.target: Mount the Windows image.

segment.source: The mounting process maps the contents of an image file to a location where you can view and modify the mounted image.
segment.target: The mounting process maps the contents of an image file to a location where you can view and modify the mounted image.

segment.source: Where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image and 1 is the index of the image that you want to use.
segment.target: Where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image and 1 is the index of the image that you want to use.

segment.source: This step can take several minutes.
segment.target: This step can take several minutes.

segment.source: Copy the answer file into the image into the WindowsPanther folder, and name it unattend.xml.
segment.target: Copy the answer file into the image into the WindowsPanther folder, and name it unattend.xml.

segment.source: Create the folder if it doesn’t exist.
segment.target: Create the folder if it doesn’t exist.

segment.source: If there’s an existing answer file, replace it or use Windows System Image Manager to edit/combine settings if necessary.
segment.target: If there’s an existing answer file, replace it or use Windows System Image Manager to edit/combine settings if necessary.

segment.source: Commit the changes and unmount the Windows image:
segment.target: Commit the changes and unmount the Windows image:

segment.source: where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image.
segment.target: where C is the drive letter of the drive that contains the image.

segment.source: This process may take several minutes.
segment.target: This process may take several minutes.

segment.source: Verify your customizations
segment.target: Verify your customizations

segment.source: Apply the Windows image to a new device as described in Lab 2: Classic-style deployment, Step 15: Apply Windows images using a script.
segment.target: Apply the Windows image to a new device as described in Lab 2: Classic-style deployment, Step 15: Apply Windows images using a script.

segment.source: When audit mode starts, the script should start automatically.
segment.target: When audit mode starts, the script should start automatically.

segment.source: In File Explorer, check to see if the file: C:FabrikamDxDiag-TestLogFiles.txt exists.
segment.target: In File Explorer, check to see if the file: C:FabrikamDxDiag-TestLogFiles.txt exists.

segment.source: If so, your sample script ran correctly.
segment.target: If so, your sample script ran correctly.

segment.source: While in Audit mode, you can start Lab 2b: Windows desktop apps and data: capturing changes.
segment.target: While in Audit mode, you can start Lab 2b: Windows desktop apps and data: capturing changes.
